page.title: 08PRONY HILL FARM
page.content: Hill sheep farming methods have not become mechanised in the same way that lowland farms have in recent years. Arable fields are small and steep and the livestock are run on vast area of rough ground. Most arable land is used to grow hay, silage and turrnips, to keep the livestock during the cold, snowy winter. The breeds of sheep most common on Scottish hill farms are Cheviot and Scottish Blackface, both hardy breeds. The main product of the hill farm comes from the sale of lambs, often to Europe and the Arab countries. The wool from the adult sheep is also sold but now competition from man-made fibres has reduced its importance.
